Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences in Marine Organism Health: Resilience and Response to Environmental Change
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to the College of Charleston that will provide research training for 10 students for 10 weeks, during the summers of 2011 - 2013. This project is also supported by the Division of Ocean Sciences (OCE) in the Directorate for Geosciences. The Program focuses on the multidisciplinary theme of Marine Organism Health: Resilience and Response to Environmental Change, investigating the impacts of climate change, natural disasters, pollution, and coastal development. There is a wide variety of research projects available to students, ranging from marine organisms at the individual level, to the community and population levels. REU students are expected to do full-time lab research as well as participate in seminars, field trips and various workshops, such as responsible conduct in research, communication with professional, educational and public audiences, and the graduate school application process. REU students are expected to live on-site in the dormitory of the Grice Marine Laboratory at the Fort Johnson Marine Resources Center. They have access to a wide array of laboratory and field equipment both within individual mentor labs and shared facilities of the federal and state laboratories at Fort Johnson. The program's multi-phase recruitment effort consists of both traditional mailings and flyers, digital-based advertising and personal contacts. Participants are selected based on outstanding academic and personal achievement, on the potential benefits of the research experience to them, and on the diversity that the student brings to the group. Students are tracked to determine their continued interest in science and math disciplines, their career paths, and the lasting influences of the research experience. Information about the program will be assessed by various means, including use of an REU common assessment tool. More information is available by visiting http://www.coc.edu/reu or by contacting the PI (Dr. Lou Burnett at burnettl@cofc.edu) or the Co-PI (Dr. Karen Burnett at burnettk@cofc.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award supported the Fort Johnson Undergraduate Summer Research Program during the summers of 2011-2013, providing independent research opportunities for 29 undergraduates drawn from 27 colleges and universities across 21 United States and Territories during the summers of 2011-2013. Program research and supporting activities centered on the multidisciplinary theme of Marine Organism Health: Resilience and Response to Environmental Change. The student interns investigated the impacts of climate change, natural disasters, pollution, and coastal development on the health of marine organisms as individuals, communities, populations and species. Faculty research mentors were drawn from more than 100 PhD scientists whose primary appointments lie within the Medical University of South Carolina, the National Institute of Standards and Technology, the National Ocean Service and the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources, all of which are located the Marine Resources Research Center at Fort Johnson, near Charleston, SC. In addition to independent research, the Program included a variety of lectures, field trips and workshops focused on key aspects of professional development including ethics, scientific writing, development of research proposals and manuscripts, oral presentations, as well as graduate school and careers, promoting the development of future scientific workforce.

 

The Program succeeded in generating good science and preparing promising undergraduates for careers in science. Formal assessments indicated that students gained skills in formulating hypotheses, writing proposals, designing experiments, data collection and recording, statistical analyses, oral presentations, and writing scientific papers. They also gained technical skills reflecting the needs of their individual projects, for example mass spectrometry, bacterial community sequencing, qPCR, electron microscopy, microsatellite analysis, and flow cytometry. Program participants have been co-authors on four publications in the peer-reviewed literature and eight additional manuscripts are in various stages of preparation. Eleven of participants in this REU are currently enrolled in graduate STEM programs and an additional three will apply to graduate school in 2015-2016. Another four students are working in STEM-related fields and will likely move into graduate programs within the next three years. Thus, we expect that at least 18 of the 29 student researchers trained in the Fort Johnson Undergraduate Summer Research Program with support from this award (62%) will enter graduate school in a STEM discipline within the next three years.

The Program also clearly succeeded in achieving its broader goals to promote diversity and communication skills in the future science workforce. Women comprised 62% while minorities (black and Hispanic) constituted 38% of the Program interns. All interns received training and exercised their skills in talking and writing about their research with professional audiences, K-12 students and the public. The communication component of the 2013 REU Program culminated in the installation of a touring public display entitled "Marine Organism Health: Resilience and Response to Environmental Change," which remained on display in multiple public venues in the Charleston area from October 2013 to May 2014. A virtual tour of the display is available on line at (https://prezi.com/kheccnjewi0h/marine-organismal-health-resilience-and-response-to-environmental-change/). In summary, the Fort Johnson Undergraduate Summer Research Program achieved all of its stated intellectual and broader goals as originally conceived.
